item.title: By: dreeves
item.dc:creator: dreeves
item.description: Manoel, great question! But I'm out of my depth for trying to apply concepts like akrasia to organizations or societies as opposed to individuals. I'm not sure they do apply, except perhaps by analogy.
item.content:encoded: Manoel, great question! But I’m out of my depth for trying to apply concepts like akrasia to organizations or societies as opposed to individuals. I’m not sure they do apply, except perhaps by analogy.

item.title: By: Manoel Galdino
item.dc:creator: Manoel Galdino
item.description:
I don't understand completly your idea of Akrasia horizon. But I'd like to hear from you what you think of what happened to Argentina in the nineties. Economists used to say that Argentina, by put in law the parity 1 peso = 1 dollar, committed itself to be fiscally responsible, after all, if not, there would be a huge crises. And then a lot of money flew to Argentina. But because it was a so perfect mechanism, I mean, it really had to work, they could be lazy, and indeed they were fiscally irresponsible. And, in the end, there was a huge crisis.
best, Manoel
ps.: I really like this subject. In fact, it's somewhat related to my B.A thesis (in economics), which was about how economists developed the idea that people evaluate differently present and future (in the works of Bhöm-Bawerk, Irving Fisher and John Bates Clark). I didn't pursue researching in the subject as a grad student, but I still like it.
item.content:encoded:
I don’t understand completly your idea of Akrasia horizon. But I’d like to hear from you what you think of what happened to Argentina in the nineties. Economists used to say that Argentina, by put in law the parity 1 peso = 1 dollar, committed itself to be fiscally responsible, after all, if not, there would be a huge crises. And then a lot of money flew to Argentina. But because it was a so perfect mechanism, I mean, it really had to work, they could be lazy, and indeed they were fiscally irresponsible. And, in the end, there was a huge crisis.

best,
Manoel

ps.: I really like this subject. In fact, it’s somewhat related to my B.A thesis (in economics), which was about how economists developed the idea that people evaluate differently present and future (in the works of Bhöm-Bawerk, Irving Fisher and John Bates Clark). I didn’t pursue researching in the subject as a grad student, but I still like it.
